So looking forward to this - exactly the kind of thing I've been looking for (as that is not as easy to find as one might expect). There's lots of stuff out there are about what we know or think we know now, but less so about how we got here and when the respective disciplines really because solidified. It'd be really interesting to see when we moved from alchemy to chemistry, and when the different disciplines matured a different times (i.e. we've had maths and physics as more solidly scientific disciplines far longer than say psychology). Excited.

Aristotle was the opposite of a scientist.  His (and Plato's) approach to natural philosophy was so antithetical to science that it shunted human intellectual growth for centuries.  Aristotle meant well, but he was nearly always wrong--not merely wrong in description, prediction, and explanation, but more fundamentally wrong epistemically.  His only role in the history of science is antagonistic.
He [or she] who can not draw on three thousand years is living from hand to mouth.
